name: The Trophy at Dawn
description: I’ve been sitting here in the gallery since five a.m., the rain tapping soft on the windows. The light is low, golden, like it’s just waking up. The victim, Mr. Ellington, was found slumped over the grand marble table, his face still turned toward the glass. The trophy—his old college one—was right where he’d been holding it. Now it’s half-buried in the dust, the stem cracked, the gold dimmed. I don’t know who took it, or why, but I know one thing: someone wanted to remember the past, and someone just wanted to erase it.

victim.name: Elena Marquez
victim.description: Elena Marquez, a seasoned art curator in her late 40s, carries the quiet intensity of a woman who has seen the ebb and flow of the art world's rhythms. With a sharp gaze and a penchant for vintage novels, she moves through the city like a shadow, always on the hunt for meaning beneath the surface. A devoted daughter to a working-class family, she balanced her ambition with the quiet grace of a woman who never wanted to be the center of attention. Her life was one of subtle contrasts—elegant yet grounded, emotionally reserved yet deeply empathetic. Known for her uncanny ability to sense the mood in a room, Elena was not just a curator but a storyteller of art, weaving narratives that brought forgotten masterpieces to life. When she was found dead in her apartment, the crime scene suggested a sudden, violent interruption of her routine—her life, it seemed, had been upended just as she was about to present a new exhibit on the forgotten stories of noir artists.

She says she saw a man entering the café at 21:28 and heard him talking to the barista about 'a surprise opening.' She believes the man might have been the artist's friend, but she has no way of confirming this. She has been working late to finalize her own gallery submission and may have been distracted.

secrets.text: Elena has been in a secret affair with the artist's longtime assistant, who recently expressed interest in joining the artist's gallery. The assistant has been quietly documenting the artist's daily routines and has noticed subtle changes in the artist's behavior, including growing distant from the assistant.

Elena discovered that she was the one who originally commissioned the artist to create a series of paintings for a gallery space that she now owns. The artist had been painting these works without credit, and when Elena asked for recognition, the artist declined, citing 'creative differences.' This secret has been building for years and represents a deep betrayal of trust.

suspects.name: Elena Marquez

She says she walked home through the neighborhood, stopping at a streetlamp near the park to sketch. However, her sketchbook shows only a few pages of notes and faint pencil lines, suggesting she was not actively engaged in the event.
suspects.motive: Elena feels betrayed when the victim publicly praised a former collaborator—someone Elena had hoped would become her next muse. She believes the victim’s recent success is a direct threat to her own career and has been secretly working to undermine her.

secrets.text: Elena has been secretly submitting paintings to the same gallery that the victim curated, but under a different name to avoid direct competition. She also borrowed a set of the victim’s sketches from a past exhibition, which she claims were used for inspiration.

Elena discovered that the victim had been secretly planning to retire and hand over her gallery space to a younger artist—someone Elena had recently been mentoring. The victim had even offered a generous share of the profits from the upcoming exhibit to this new artist. This revelation explains the depth of the motive and suggests a personal betrayal.

Her cab receipt lists a drop-off at the street corner near the murder scene at 10:30 PM, which aligns with the timeline but doesn't account for the murder occurring at 21:28.
suspects.motive: Elena believes the victim’s latest exhibition will overshadow her own upcoming solo show. With the victim's recent success, Elena fears her own career momentum will slow down. She has been secretly planning to sabotage the exhibition by subtly altering key pieces and even delaying the opening.

Elena discovered that the victim had been secretly writing a memoir about their early years, which included a chapter dedicated to Elena—claiming she had once been a protégé and had been passed over for key recognition. The chapter reveals that the victim had a deep personal debt to Elena’s family, which she never acknowledged publicly. This secret could be a major point of contention if revealed.
